ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Alternative fitness sharing method
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Joel, ... I ve read it just now (thanks) and I think you ll have to take my word on that because as far as I can tell we both arrived at pretty much the

Hi Joel,

On 18 April 2011 00:23, joel278 <lehman.154@...> wrote:
> Have you had a chance to read Ken and I's recent publication on novelty search and
> local competition: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/lehman.gecco11.html?
> Some of the ideas we introduce there are somewhat similar in spirit to what you are
> suggesting.

I've read it just now (thanks) and I think you'll have to take my word
on that because as far as I can tell we both arrived at pretty much
the same conclusion, that is, multiple objectives + local competition
are key aspects of natural evolution that EC has mostly overlooked.
(That /might/ be overstating the case as I haven't performed a survey
of the EC literature, but I don't think so).


> In that publication we apply NS to evolve virtual creatures. We look
> both for creatures with novel morphologies and those that have high
> fitness relative to their morphological niche.

So the minor difference in where we ended up as I see it is that I'm
talking about multiple fitness metrics that would each stand as a
target objective in their own right (from a traditional EC point of
view), and I'm thinking that this would result in enough complexity in
the fitness space that you wouldn't need to define an 'artificial'
(e.g. novelty) metric to help nudge you into good regions of the
fitness space. I guess it's a fairly subtle point and possibly a
flawed one since it relies on a distinction between a 'real' objectve
and what I just called an 'artificial' objective (an objective you
don't care about by itself but that you think will help guide a search
into useful regions of the search space to help the 'real'
objectives).


> This seems somewhat related to your idea, although yours involves additional
> evaluations and weighted averages of different fitnesses depending on the X,Y niching
> coordinates.

Again I feel there are only minor differences here. I put two
functions on each axis of my example 2D niche space - so on one axis
you move from being good at f1 to being good at f2:

     f1<---->f2

If I'm understanding your's and Ken's paper right you effectively have
the same type of space but with one fitness metric/function per axis.
Because I was looking at the niche space as weighted fitness functions
I wanted to avoid having a corner of the space where all the weights
were zero - hence I put a balance between *two* functions on each axis
(you actually only need to do this for one axis to avoid the 'zero
corner'). But then (A) it might be that having a zero weighted corner
isn't such a bad thing and (B) I may not have fully understood how you
combined your multiple objectives.


> Your suggestion of a more general conception of incremental evolution
> is interesting as well. One problem with incremental evolution
> is that you have to know both what the stepping stones are and the order in which they
> should be discovered to create some sort of training plan. Your generalization might
> alleviate the need to know the "order" of the stepping stones because genomes can
> specialize to whatever objective they are most suited to (by changing their XY through
> mutation).

Absolutely, that's the hope. I'd also say that specifying one linear
directed order of discrete steps is very limiting. This alternative
approach potentially provides multiple smooth pathways and even
reverse and possibly oscillating pathways (think of
fish->mammals->dolphins as a very high level example).


> Anyways, I look forward to seeing your idea further developed, it seems like a cool
> approach to potentially evolve more complex things.

Thanks and thanks for the paper. I especially enjoyed the videos BTW,
some of those examples were quite amusing I thought :)

Colin
